Hmmm, I guess black didn't want me to exchange my knight for his bishop. I feel that exchange would have been weak for white. As played, the bishop was crucial to black's defense of the d6 pawn. The defender removed, I see no reason to show mercy.

Hmmm, I guess black didn't want me to exchange my knight for his bishop. I feel that exchange would have been weak for white. As played, the bishop was crucial to black's defense of the d6 pawn. The defender removed, I see no reason to show mercy.

Black added a piece to support his attack against my knight on d6. Moving the knight will allow black to trade queens, but I am OK with that since I'm a pawn ahead. F5 was tempting, but I chose c4 because I'm considering the havoc I can play against black's pawn structure if he'll let the knight exchange for the bishop on b6.

I thought I had it all worked out. I am now threatening to win black's knight on e4 and also to win the pawn on b5: If 21. ... Nf6, 22. Nxf6  followed by 23. Pxb5. Or if 21. ... Ng5, 22. Pxb5 and now black can choose to exchange knights or allow both knights to run to safety.

I thought I had it all worked out. I am now threatening to win black's knight on e4 and also to win the pawn on b5: If 21. ... Nf6, 22. Nxf6  followed by 23. Pxb5. Or if 21. ... Ng5, 22. Pxb5 and now black can choose to exchange knights or allow both knights to run to safety.
This was probably a mistake on my part. I think I was better off with 22. Pxb5.
This was probably a mistake on my part. I think I was better off with 22. Pxb5.

I didn't see 22. ... Nd4 coming. Ouch. I really should have, since it was such a nice and obvious move. White cannot counter attack black's queen with 23. Nc7? since 23. ... Nxe2 gives check and lets black save his own queen. 23. Qd3? is met by 23. ... Pxc4 and now both the white queen and white knight are en prise and one must fall. The remaining retreats for the white queen offer no interesting attacks and allow black to play 23. ... Pxc4, recovering some of his lost material and gaining a well-supported passed pawn in the process. So I decide I am better off choosing the fashion in which I give back some of my material lead instead of letting black take it for himself as he chooses.

Black had the chance to take the white rook with 23. ... Pxd4 but he chose to refuse my gift. Truth is, I am not sure I get much compensation for returning the exchange, so I'm fairly glad black refused the gift. As played, white can retain his material advantage.

Double the rooks on the c-file.

I capitalize on a bit of a miscalculation by black by skewering his queen to his e5 pawn. The queen must move, and then the pawn will fall, leaving me with a winning material advantage.
I capitalize on a bit of a miscalculation by black by skewering his queen to his e5 pawn. The queen must move, and then the pawn will fall, leaving me with a winning material advantage.

There. Winning edge secured, and I've gained an attack as well. I must remain ever vigilant of my back rank or this game could end in a single nasty surprise. However, pressing the attack does not give me time to create breathing room for my king, so I will have to be careful.
